Award.AwardTitle: Student Participant Support for the ICSE 2011 Doctoral Symposium

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This grant supports travel by doctoral students to the Doctoral Symposium at the International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE). ICSE is the flagship conference for the area of Software Engineering, providing a forum for researchers, practitioners, and educators to present and discuss the most recent innovations, trends, experiences, and concerns in the field of Software Engineering. The Doctoral Symposium at ICSE provides a venue for young researchers to access worldwide expertise in Software Engineering. The Symposium provides a forum for Ph.D. students to present and discuss their research goals, methods, and results at an early stage in their research. The Symposium aims to provide useful guidance to the students from a panel of experts, for completion of the dissertation research and initiation of a research career. The opportunity to attend one of the premier conferences in Software Engineering is intended to provide experiences that may encourage students to pursue higher degrees in computer science research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The annual International Conference on Software Engineering (ICSE) is the premier forum for the presentation of new results in the field, which is concerned with the processes, techniques, and tools used in designing and developing computer software.  The Doctoral Symposium associated with ICSE is directed at guiding the research paths of the upcoming generation of Ph.D. researchers, while there is still sufficient time before their graduation to genuinely impact the course of their work.  The NSF grant is used solely to enable student participation in the event, by providing travel assistance for some, and partial defrayment of registration fees for others.

 

The ICSE 2011 Doctoral Symposium was held Monday, May 23, 2011 from 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. at the conference venue. ?The goals of the Doctoral Symposium were to provide a supportive yet questioning setting in which Ph.D. students could present their work; to provide an opportunity for students to attend ICSE; and to support the ICSE mission as a world-leading venue for software engineering research. Students were able to discuss their goals, methods, and results at an? early stage in their research. The Symposium aimed to provide students with useful guidance and feedback on various aspects of their research from a panel of established researchers and the other student attendees. It helped participants establish a research and social network of their peers from around the world. Students also gained critical feedback on their presentation skills. All Doctorial Symposium participants were, additionally, invited to present posters in a special session held in association with the main conference.

 

The Symposium was a closed forum, open only to the committee and invited students.  Students were invited based upon proposals submitted in response to a public call for submissions to a committee of reviewers. Twenty-one students attended the Symposium, of which five were female. Both students and faculty organizers viewed the ICSE 2011 Doctoral Symposium as a success, with excellent discussions. Informal conversations with the participating students after the event indicated that they greatly valued the experience.
